Ltd., Quzhou 324299, China Rianlon Kerun (Zhejiang) New Material Co. Ltd. Quzhou 324299 China bRianlon Kerun (Zhejiang) New Material Co. Ltd., Quzhou 324299, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Defective metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) supported Pt catalysts with hydrogenation-alkaline dual active sites were designed for the catalytic hydrogenation of 2-(2′‑hydroxy-5′-methylphenyl) azobenzene (HAB) to 2-(2′- hydroxy‑5′-methylphenyl) benzotriazole nitrogen oxide (NO compound). The catalyst showed a very promising selectivity (98.11 %) toward NO compound production at a complete conversion of HAB without additional base. Comprehensive characterizations reveal that addition of hydrazine hydrate leads to the breaking of the Zr-O bond in the MOFs, forming abundant unsaturated zirconium ion. This defect structure could induce a strong metal support interaction between Pt and MOFs, which alters the electronic state of Pt into an electron-deficient state, leading to a stronger bonding to the nitrogen-nitrogen double bond in the azobenzene molecule. Moreover, the breakage of Zr-O bond generated abundant Lewis basic site (negatively charged O atoms), which is the key reason for the improvement of the reaction selectivity due to the hydrogenation-alkaline dual active sites. These results pave a promising way for designing supported Pt metal catalysts in terms of the practical route to NO compound production. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Alkali-free system Catalytic hydrogenation Metal-organic framework Dual active site Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction As an important benzotriazole ultraviolet absorbers, 2-(2′‑hydroxy-5′-methylphenyl) benzotriazole (UV-P) is widely used for the protection of plastics against sunlight due to its wide range of absorption wavelengths (300∼385 nm), anti-discoloration, non-volatility and good compatibility [1,2]. The current major industrial production methods for UV-P is through catalytic reduction of 2-(2′‑hydroxy-5′-methylphenyl) benzotriazole nitrogen oxide (NO compound) with zinc powder in the presence of alkaline reagent [3]. Although the traditional process is scalable and technologically mature, the serious pollution caused by zinc sludge and lye is against the 12 principles of green chemistry [4]. The catalytic hydrogenation of 2-nitro-(2′‑hydroxy-5′-methylphenyl) azobenzene (HAB) to NO compound is a clean process with high efficiency and low cost, which is currently recognized as an ideal alternative route for UV-P synthesis (Fig. 1 ) [5-7]. In this route, the synthesis of intermediate products NO compound from azobenzene compound raw materials requires extra basic additives to improve reaction yield and is generally acknowledged as the rate-determining step. Therefore, one of the most critical challenges for this route is the development of catalyst to establish an alkaline-free reaction system with improved NO compound selectivity. Various transition metal catalysts, including Pt, Pd, Ni, etc., have been studied as candidates for this process [8-12]. Among them, supported Pt-based catalysts are commonly used in the hydrogenation of HAB to NO compound because of their high activity [13-15]. For supported catalysts, the acid/base character and textural properties of support could affect their geometric and electronic properties via strong metal-support interactions (SMSI), thereby modulating catalytic performance. According to previous works [13-15], solid base, which possesses high activity in various reactions under mild conditions with minimum dozes of pollutants, is proposed as the effective substitute of the homogeneous base catalyst Therefore, by using solid base-hydrogenation bifunctional catalysts, the existence of alkaline sites on the surface of the hydrogenation catalyst would facilitate the reductive cyclization under alkaline-free conditions. Christine et al. [16] investigated the gas phase condensation of butyraldehyde and isobutyraldehyde on a solid base catalyst (4 wt.%Na on SiO2) and a combined solid base/hydrogenation catalyst (0.1 wt.%Pd/4 wt.%Na/SiO2). Pd/Na/SiO2 catalysts can be used to produce selectively hydrogenated aldol condensation product 2-ethylhexal from butanal feed with high selectivity (maximum 94.9 % at 42.4 % conversion). Si et al. [17] prepared an alkali metal K-doped palladium solid base hydrogenation bifunction catalyst and applied it to the hydrogenation of 2-nitro-2′‑hydroxy-5′-methylazobenzene. The selectivity of the catalyst for benzotriazole was 84.79 %. The alkaline site guarantees the selectivity of benzotriazole. Yet, solid base-hydrogenation bifunctional catalysts have been rarely reported in the catalytic hydrogenation of HAB to NO compound. Metal organic frameworks (MOFs), a fascinating material with porous surfaces [18,19],and highly designable [20] properties have attracted much research attentions. Liu et al. [21] prepared strong base sites directly on metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) by using guest-subject REDOX (GHR) interactions between base precursors and low-price metal centers, such as Cr3+, which broke with the tradition of thermally induced decomposition of pre-base bodies. Here, the alkali precursor KNO3 can be converted to a strongly alkaline species at MIL-53 (Cr) at 300 °C, which is much lower than the conversion rate at Y zeolite (700 °C) and mesoporous silica SBA-15 (600 °C). In this work, a defective MOFs supported Pt catalyst with hydrogenation-alkaline dual active site was designed for the catalytic hydrogenation of HAB to NO compound. The effect of different treatment on the catalyst structure were studied by multiple characterization techniques, including X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 adsorption-desorption, Transmission electron micrograph (TEM), Fourier transformed infrared spectra (FT-IR), and Thermal gravity analysis (TGA). Advanced characterization and analysis, including X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and CO2-temperature programmed desorption (TPD), to explore the interaction between Pt NPs and their supporting matrix. Moreover, the properties of as-prepared catalysts with different structure were correlated to the activity/selectivity of the hydrogenation of HAB. The experimental data and insights revealed here would provide a fundamental understanding of the Pt-based bifunctional catalytic mechanism. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of UiO-66-NH2 ZrCl4 (0.8 g, 3.4 mmol), 2-aminoterephthalic acid (0.6 g, 3.4 mmol) and glacial acetic acid (2.058 g, 34 mmol) were added to 175 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF). The resulting mixed solution was then transferred into a 200 mL stainless steel reaction vessel with a polytetrafluoroethylene (PPL) liner, sealed and heated to 120 °C for 24 h. The resulting precipitate was centrifuged and washed with DMF, methanol and water for 3 times, and then dried in vacuum at 80 °C for 12 h to obtain UiO-66-NH2 carrier. The UiO-66 carrier was prepared in a similar manner, as long as the ligand 2-aminoterephthalic acid was replaced with terephthalic acid. 2.2 Preparation of Fe-MIL-101-NH2 FeCl3 (4.05 g, 24.97 mmol), 2-aminoterephthalic acid (2.25 g, 12.42 mmol) and H2O (2.7 g, 150 mmol) were added to DMF (150 mL), and the resulting mixed solution was transferred into a 200 mL stainless steel reaction vessel with a polytetrafluoroethylene (PPL) liner, sealed and heated to 110 °C for 24 h. The resulting precipitate was centrifuged and washed with DMF, methanol and water for 3 times, and then dried in vacuum at 80 °C for 12 h to obtain Fe-MIL-101-NH2 carrier. 2.3 Preparation of loaded catalyst 2% Pt/UiO-66-NH2 Taking the Pt loading of 2 wt% as an example: 1.5 g of the above UiO-66-NH2 carrier and H2PtCl6·6H2O (0.0813 g, 0.157 mmol) were added into 8 mL of aqueous solution, stirred uniformly, and impregnated for 12 h. 10 mL of NaOH with the concentration of 0.04 g/mL was added into the solution, and the PH was adjusted to 11 (drop acceleration rate of 60 mL/h), and then 0.554 g of hydrazine hydrate (drop acceleration rate of 60 mL/h) was added and reduced at 50 °C for 12 h. filtered and washed. The catalyst was filtered and washed, and dried at 80 °C for 6 h in a vacuum oven to produce 2 % Pt/UiO-66-NH2 catalyst. Other MOFs carrier catalysts were prepared in a similar manner. 2.4 Preparation of encapsulated catalyst 2% Pt@UiO-66-NH2 ZrCl4 (0.8 g, 3.4 mmol), 2-aminoterephthalic acid (0.6 g, 3.4 mmol), H2PtCl6·6H2O (0.0759 g, 0.147 mmol), and glacial acetic acid (2.058 g, 34 mmol) were added to DMF (175 mL), and the resulting mixture was transferred to a 200 mL stainless steel reaction vessel lined with polytetrafluoroethylene (PPL), sealed and heated to 120 °C for 24 h. The resulting precipitate was centrifuged and washed 3 times with DMF, methanol and water respectively, and then dried in vacuum at 80 °C for 12 h. The catalyst prepared above was reduced at 200 °C for 2 h in H2 atmosphere to produce a 2 % Pt@UiO-66-NH2 catalyst. Catalyst characterization methods and experimental methods can be found in SI. 3 Results and discussion As shown in Fig. 2 , characteristic peaks at 7.2°, 8.4°, 25.7° and 30.7° illustrate the main phase of MOFs structure. For the UiONH2 series catalysts, the XRD patterns of 2 % Pt/UiONH2 (H2 reduction) and 2 % Pt@UiONH2 (H2 reduction) displayed the same crystal structure compared to the parent UiONH2, suggesting H2 reduction does not disrupt the crystal structure of MOFs supports. weak diffraction peak corresponding to the face-centered cubic (FCC) metallic Pt (111) planes is found, indicating agglomerated Pt NPs in the loaded catalyst 2 % Pt/UiONH2 (H2 reduction); whereas no obvious peaks of Pt NPs are detected in the encapsulated catalyst 2 % Pt@UiONH2 (H2 reduction), suggesting the significantly small sizes of Pt NPs on the supports. TEM images clearly show that Pt NPs are uniformly deposited on MOFs supports, demonstrating the fact that Pt NPs are encapsulated inside the cavity of the MOFs materials. This result reveal that the particle sizes of Pt NPs are remarkably related to the catalyst synthetic process. In contrast, under the condition of hydrazine hydrate, the catalyst structure is significantly changed due to the phase transition in catalyst synthesis process. The characteristic peaks of Pt are observed, due to partially disrupted crystal structure of the MOFs and formation of defective sites. Furthermore, the significant difference in XRD patterns for the UiO-66 series catalysts (Fig. 3 ) reveals that the surface structure of the MOFs supports reduced by hydrazine hydrate has been destroyed. The crystal structures of as-prepared samples are further analyzed by HRTEM images. As shown in Fig. 4 , the MOFs carrier prepared by hydrothermal method shows a complete ortho-octahedron structure, which matches well with the XRD results. From the high-angle annular dark field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) of 2 % Pt@UiONH2 (H2 reduction) catalyst (Fig. 4b and c), it can be seen that a large number of spherical nanoparticles are uniformly dispersed on the support surface with an average particle size of 1.51 nm. In contrast, the size of Pt NPs in the 2 % Pt/UiONH2 (H2 reduction) catalyst is in the range of 5–8 nm, with an average particle size of 6.39 nm. From the TEM images, it can be seen that most of the Pt NPs in the 2 % Pt@UiONH2 (H2 reduction) catalyst are distributed in the internal cavities of the MOFs carriers, while most of the Pt NPs in the 2 % Pt/UiONH2 (H2 reduction) catalyst are agglomerated on the external surfaces of MOFs carriers. In Fig. 4d, the 2 % Pt/UiONH2 (hydrazine hydrate reduction) catalyst under the reduction condition of hydrazine hydrate, the surface structure of the MOFs carrier is disrupted and a large number of defective sites are generated on its surface. This unique structure provides more anchoring sites for Pt NPs to coordinate with the unsaturated Zr ions thus more electron-deficient states of Pt NPs are obtained. Besides, for the 2 % Pt/UiONH2 (hydrazine hydrate reduction) catalysts, agglomerated Pt NPs with an average particle size of 21.47 nm on the MOFs surface are clearly seen in Fig. 4d1. More pronounced lattice fringes are present in all three catalysts, and the measured lattice spacings of approximately 0.227 nm and 0.195 nm are corresponding to the face-centered cubic (FCC) Pt (111) and (200) crystal planes respectively. To further quantitate the basicity in as-prepared materials, CO2-TPD analysis was performed. As shown in Fig. 5 , a desorption peak at 512 K for the decomposition of the MOFs carrier is observed, which deriving from CO2 desorption from the Lewis basic site of the Zr6 node μ3 O [22]. The CO2 desorption behavior of 2 % Pt@UiONH2 (H2 reduction) catalyst and 2 % Pt/UiONH2 (H2 reduction) catalyst are similar to those of UiONH2 carrier. As for the 2 % Pt/UiONH2 (hydrazine hydrate reduction) catalyst, a desorption peak at relatively low temperatures (363 K) is observed, which is produced from disruption of Lewis basic sites for μ3 O [23].These results indicate that the catalysts with fewer defective sites possess weak basic sites. The corresponding base amount values at each peak were evaluated based on the peak areas, listed in Table 1 . Similar results can be observed in UiO-66 and Fe-MIL-101-NH2 supported catalysts (Fig. 5c and f). Therefore, when the catalyst was reduced by hydrazine hydrate, it was able to produce weakly basic sites, which could promote the occurrence of the ring-forming reaction of HAB-catalyzed hydrogenation, inhibit the breaking of the NN bond, and improve the selectivity of the reaction. The reason for the low selectivity of NO compound and many bond-breaking by-products in 2 % Pt/Fe-MIL-101-NH2 (hydrazine hydrate reduction) catalysts despite the presence of weakly basic sites is due to the fact that not only Pt4+ is reduced to Pt NPs by hydrazine hydrate during the reduction process, but also Fe3+ is reduced to Fe2+, and the coordination of Fe2+ with Pt NPs leads to the electron-rich state of Pt NPs to gain electrons, which makes the dissociative hydrogen capacity of Pt NPs stronger, resulting in the hydrogenation capacity of the active component in the catalyst being much higher than the inhibition of bond breaking capacity of the weakly basic sites, which leads to a large increase in the by-products in the reaction. The above results can prove that the catalyst under hydrazine hydrate reduction condition produces basic sites in the HAB-catalyzed hydrogenation reaction, and the selectivity of NO compound is much higher than that of the catalyst under H2 reduction condition, it corresponds to the experimental results. XPS measurement was carried out to investigate the electronic structure of the as-synthesized Pt catalysts. As presented in Fig. 6 and Table 2 , the Pt 4f XPS spectra can be deconvoluted into two doublets peaks, the one at 71.9 eV corresponding to Pt 4f7/2 and the other at 74.6 eV corresponding to Pt 4f5/2. The characteristic peak with a binding energy of Pt 4f7/2 at 71.95 eV in the hydrazine hydrate-reduced 2 % Pt/UiONH2 (hydrazine hydrate-reduced) catalyst can be assigned to Pt0, and the characteristic peak with a binding energy at 75.05 eV can be assigned to Pt4+ (existing in the form of oxidized to PtO2 or unreduced PtCl6 2−). The Pt 4f7/2 peak of the hydrazine hydrate-reduced Pt/UiONH2 catalyst is shifted toward higher binding energy in comparison with that of the hydrogen-reduced catalysts, which indicates that the Pt NPs in the reduced state form a coordination with the unsaturated Zr ions produced by the destruction of the surface structure of the MOFs, so that the Pt NPs take on an electron-deficient state, and the electron-deficient state of the Pt NPs is more likely to be combined with the nitrogen-nitrogen double bond of azobenzene feedstocks, which corresponds to the weakening of the Zr-O bond in the infrared spectrum [24]. The encapsulated catalyst 2 % Pt@UiONH2 (H2 reduction) presents about 0.14 eV lower binding energy than that of the 2 % Pt/UiONH2 (H2 reduction) and 2 % Pt@UiONH2 (H2 reduction) catalysts. This probably is because most of the Pt NPs in Pt@UiONH2 are encapsulated in the internal cavity of the MOFs carrier thus not coordinated with the unsaturated Zr ions on the carrier external surface, resulting in a weaker electron transfer from Zr to Pt. In order to further investigate the interaction between the reduced state Pt NPs and Zr ions, the Zr 3d orbitals of the catalysts were analyzed as shown in Fig. 7 and Table 3 . As shown in Fig. 7, the Zr 3d signals of 2 % Pt/UiONH2 catalyst (H2 reduction) located at 182.83 eV, 183.09 eV, and 183.79 eV attributed to Zr4+, -COO-Zr, and Zr-OH, respectively. Comparing with the H2-reduced catalysts, it can be clearly found that the Zr4+ binding energy is shifted to a lower binding energy than that in the catalyst obtained by hydrazine hydrate reduction, indicating more defects on the surface structure of the hydrazine hydrate-reduced catalyst carriers. These binding energy shifts suggest a stronger interaction between Pt NPs and the Zr ions in the catalyst obtained by hydrazine hydrate reduction. From the curves of N2 physical adsorption-desorption in Figs. 8 and 9 , it can be seen that those three samples, UiONH2, 2 % Pt/UiONH2 (H2 reduction), and 2 % Pt@UiONH2 (H2 reduction), showed a rapid increase in adsorption when P/P0 was lower than 0.1, and then the rate of adsorption was significantly reduced and adsorption stabilized when it was greater than 0.1, The smaller hysteresis loop indicates that the pore structure of the MOFs carrier is not disrupted and the pore structure is dominated by micropores. While 2 % Pt/UiONH2 (hydrazine hydrate reduction) and 2 % Pt/Fe-MIL-101-NH2 (hydrazine hydrate reduction) showed obvious hysteresis loops, indicating that, after hydrazine hydrate reduction, the MOFs carriers were converted from microporous to mesoporous and the pore structure was disrupted, which corresponded to the TEM and XRD results. Table 4 shows the test results of specific surface area, pore volume and average pore size of 2 % Pt/UiONH2 (H2 reduction), 2 % Pt@UiONH2 (H2 reduction), 2 % Pt/UiONH2 (hydrazine hydrate reduction), 2 % Pt/Fe-MIL-101-NH2 (hydrazine hydrate reduction) catalysts and the carrier UiONH2. It can be clearly seen that the average pore size of the samples after H2 reduction did not change greatly, while the average pore size of the samples after hydrazine hydrate reduction, increased greatly, indicating that after hydrazine hydrate reduction, the pore channels of the MOFs were disrupted, which led to a great increase in pore size. Combined with the results of the catalyst evaluation, it is possible to find out that the defective sites constructed on the surface of the carriers have a great influence on the catalytic performance of the catalysts. Fig. 10 shows the TG and DTG curves of the as-prepared carriers and catalysts For the unloaded metal component of the UiONH2 carrier (Fig. 10a), there is a distinct weight loss peak below 373 K, which can be attributed to the desorption of absorbed water, and that the weight loss peak in the range of 433∼523 K can be attributed to the removal of the DMF solvent remained inside the UiONH2 pores [25]. The weight loss peak in the range of 656∼719 K is due to the evaporation of the organic ligand 2-aminoterephthalic acid on the UiONH2 pores; the weight loss peak in the range of 788∼842 K is due to the collapse of the UiONH2 skeleton [26]. In Fig. 10b, c, and d, the weight-loss peaks for water are also present, but the weight-loss peaks for the solvent DMF are disappeared due to the fact that the DMF inside the UiONH2 was removed during catalyst preparation. The weight-loss peaks of the organic ligands in Fig. 10b and c are similar with the UiONH2 carriers in Fig. 10a, suggesting that the structure of the UiONH2 carriers did not undergo any significant changes during the H2 reduction process; The weight loss peaks of the organic ligand with the MOFs skeleton in Figure d is shifted forward than those of the other three samples, indicating the hydrazine hydrate reduction process disrupted the surface structure of the MOFs carriers, thus the organic ligand is more easily dislodged, which is consistent with the CO2-TPD results. The FT-IR spectra of each sample are exhibited in Fig. 11 . As we can see both MOFs carriers display a stretching vibration peak of C=O double bond at 1660 cm−1, indicating a small amount of DMF remained inside the UiONH2 pores. This is the reason for the lower specific surface area of the carriers, which is confirmed by the N2 physical adsorption-desorption results. While the absent of C=O stretching vibration peak at 1660 cm−1 indicates that the DMF inside the carriers has been removed in the preparation process, which is well consistent with in TG spectra; The peak located at 1250 cm−1 is the telescopic vibrational peak of CNH2, which exists only in the UiONH2 series. The vibrational peak of CNH2 in the 2 % Pt/UiONH2 catalysts after hydrazine hydrate reduction became weak, indicating that the organic skeleton of UiONH2 was destroyed during the reduction process, resulting in the shedding of the amino group, which led to the low intensity of the peak. The two peaks presenting in the carrier after hydrogen reduction located at 668 cm−1 and 769 cm−1 are generated by Zr-O bonds, while these two peaks are weak in the catalyst after hydrazine hydrate reduction, indicating that the organic skeleton of the MOFs carrier is not destroyed during hydrogen reduction. While during hydrazine hydrate process, the Zr-O bonds are broken due to the disruption of the surface structure of the MOFs carrier, leading to a weakening vibrational peak on the infrared spectra, which is in agreement with the XRD results. As can be seen from the FT-IR spectra, both UiONH2 carriers and UiO-66 carriers present an intact topology of MOFs materials under hydrogen reduction conditions. In contrast, the surface structure of the MOFs carriers is partly damaged under hydrazine hydrate reduction conditions, which makes the central Zr ions ligand-unsaturated. Consequently the active component, Pt NPs, can interact with the unsaturated Zr ions, thus enhancing the selectivity of the catalysts. 4 Evaluation In this section, catalysts prepared by different reduction methods and HAB catalytic hydrogenation to synthesize NO compound were used as evaluation reactions. The HAB conversion rate and selectivity of NO compound were investigated to determine the influence of carriers on catalytic hydrogenation reactions. The preparation method of catalysts was shown in Section 2, As can be seen from Table 5 , when the reduction condition is H2 reduction, the 2 % Pt@UiONH2 (H2 reduction) catalysts are mainly hydrotreating active components of Pt NPs that are not bound to Zr ions on the surface of the carrier due to the fact that the organic skeleton of the MOFs carrier is not destroyed. The Pt NPs in the 2 % Pt@UiONH2 (H2 reduction) catalyst are mainly distributed within the pore structure of the MOFs carrier, which results in a more homogeneous distribution of Pt NPs inside the pores and higher activity; the Pt NPs in the 2 % Pt/UiONH2 (H2 reduction) catalyst are mainly distributed on the surface of the MOFs carrier, where the Pt NPs on the surface of the carrier are subject to agglomeration and the activity is decreases, and thus the reaction selectivity decreases. When the reduction condition is hydrazine hydrate reduction, the selectivity of 2 % Pt@UiONH2 catalyst is lower than that of 2 % Pt/UiONH2 catalyst, which is due to the fact that at this time, the surface structure of the carrier is destroyed, and the active components of the hydrotreating components are mainly the Pt NPs which are bound to the Zr ions in the defective sites, and the defective sites are distributed on the surface of the carrier, and the Pt NPs encapsulated inside the pores cannot be bound to the Zr ions on the surface of the carrier. The Pt NPs could not bind to the Zr ions on the carrier surface, so the loaded catalyst 2 % Pt/UiONH2 (hydrazine hydrate reduction) was more selective under hydrazine hydrate reduction conditions. Therefore, the active component was chosen to be loaded on the MOFs material with defective surface structure by impregnation, when the reaction selectivity was the highest. The reduction method of the catalyst will lead to great changes in the morphology and active site of the catalyst. In this section, the unreduced catalyst will be reduced by hydrazine hydrate, sodium borohydride and H2 respectively, and then the reduced catalyst will be evaluated for reaction. The experimental results are shown in Table 6 . As shown in Table 6, when hydrazine hydrate is used as a reducing agent, the selectivity of NO compound reaches the maximum, which is 98.11 %, while the catalyst selectivity under H2 reduction is the lowest, which is only 59.39 %. This phenomenon may be caused by the fact that the overall structure of MOFs carrier is relatively complete during H2 reduction, and the complete MOFs carrier does not have basic sites. It is only when the Zr-O bond breaks that negatively charged O atoms appear and the Lewis base site is revealed. Therefore, hydrazine hydrate is a suitable reducing agent. The stability of the 2 % Pt/UiONH2 catalyst (hydrazine hydrate reduction) was investigated under this condition, and the experimental results are shown in Table 7 . It is very impressive that the catalyst possesses almost unchanged catalytic selectivity (above 97 %), even after being reused for as long as 10 times. The good stability of the catalyst demonstrates the unconventional robustness of the active sites on the 2 % Pt/UiONH2. 5 Mechanism The surface structure of 2 % Pt/UiONH2 (hydrazine hydrate reduction) catalyst was partially destroyed when it was reduced by hydrazine hydrate, and unsaturated Zr ions were generated from the MOFs carriers, and the empty orbitals of the Zr ions attracted the outermost electrons of the Pt NPs, and the two ligand bonded to change the electron-rich state of the Pt NPs into the electron-deficient state of the Pt NPs, which are more likely to bind to nitrogen-nitrogen double bonds in the feedstock HAB, and the dissociated hydrogen capacity of the electron-deficient state of the Pt NPs is weaker than the electron-rich state of the Pt NPs, and it can decrease the occurrence of the side reactions; Meanwhile, due to the disruption of the surface structure of MOFs, weak Lewis basic sites are revealed on the Zr6 node μ3 O. The synergistic interaction between the electron-deficient Pt NPs and the basic sites promotes intramolecular dehydration ring formation and the generation of NO compound. The dual active centers hydrogenation-alkalinityare indispensable and must work synergistically with each other to produce optimal results. Hence, from the various characterization results, a possible mechanism considering the active Pt NPs and surface base sites for HAB hydrogenation to NO compound over 2 % Pt/UiONH2 catalysts is proposed (Fig. 12 ). Initially, hydrogen is first adsorbed on the Pt NPs and dissociated into highly active hydrogen atoms. At this time, the nitrogen-nitrogen double bond of HAB molecules associated on weak Lewis basic sites of MOFs to give active intermediates. Subsequently, the intermediate undergoes hydrogenation to afford nitrogen-nitrogen single bond, then the linkage compounds in the alkaline site of the action of dehydration into a ring, and finally get NO compound. 6 Conclusions In summary, we reported a facile synthesis strategy to prepare Pt-based catalyst that consist of uniformly dispersed Pt NPs chelating onto the MOF support (2 % Pt/UiONH2) and investigated their catalytic performance for the synthesis of benzotriazole nitrogen oxides (NO compound) in a base-free system. The optimal catalyst exhibited the outstanding performance with 100 % conversion and 98.11 % selectivity at 50 °C and 1.0 MPa hydrogen pressure. Moreover, the catalytic activity and NO compound selectivity remained stable after 10 cycles of catalyst recycling. XRD, TEM, BET, CO2-TPD, FT-IR, TG and XPS techniques were employed to obtain the detailed information on the structural properties and surface acid-base characteristics of supports and catalysts. Based on the various characterizations of supports and catalysts, a possible mechanism considering the active Pt NPs and surface base sites for HAB hydrogenation to NO compound was proposed. Namely, the active component Pt NPs in the 2 % Pt/UiONH2 (hydrazine hydrate reduction) catalysts were coordinated with unsaturated Zr ions on the surface of the MOFs carriers to form the electron-deficient Pt NPs, and at the same time the surface structure of the disrupted MOFs carriers provided the weakly alkaline sites, which is the key reason for the improvement of the reaction selectivity due to the hydrogenated-alkaline dual active sites on the catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Defective metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) supported Pt catalysts with hydrogenation-alkaline dual active sites were designed for the catalytic hydrogenation of 2-(2′‑hydroxy-5′-methylphenyl) azobenzene (HAB) to 2-(2′- hydroxy‑5′-methylphenyl) benzotriazole nitrogen oxide (NO compound). The catalyst showed a very promising selectivity (98.11 %) toward NO compound production at a complete conversion of HAB without additional base. Comprehensive characterizations reveal that addition of hydrazine hydrate leads to the breaking of the Zr-O bond in the MOFs, forming abundant unsaturated zirconium ion. This defect structure could induce a strong metal support interaction between Pt and MOFs, which alters the electronic state of Pt into an electron-deficient state, leading to a stronger bonding to the nitrogen-nitrogen double bond in the azobenzene molecule. Moreover, the breakage of Zr-O bond generated abundant Lewis basic site (negatively charged O atoms), which is the key reason for the improvement of the reaction selectivity due to the hydrogenation-alkaline dual active sites. These results pave a promising way for designing supported Pt metal catalysts in terms of the practical route to NO compound production.
